title: Sarcocystosis
parasite_biology:
### Causal Agents

_Sarcocystis hominis_ and _S. suihominis_ use humans as definitive hosts and
are responsible for intestinal sarcocystosis in the human host. Humans may
also become dead-end hosts for non-human _Sarcocystis_ spp. after the
accidental ingestion of oocysts.

### Life Cycle

![Lifecycle](/dpdx/sarcocystosis/modules/Sarcocystis_LifeCycle_v3.gif?_=00580)

Both sporulated oocysts (containing two sporocysts) and individual sporocysts
can be passed in stool ![The number
1](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/large_intestine_1.gif).
Sporocysts contain four sporozoites and a refractile residual body. Sporocysts
ingested by the intermediate host (cattle for _S. hominis_ and pigs for _S.
suihominis_) rupture, releasing sporozoites. Sporozoites enter endothelial
cells of blood vessels and undergo schizogony, resulting in first-generation
schizonts. Merozoites derived from the first-generation invade small
capillaries and blood vessels, becoming second-generation schizonts. The
second generation merozoites invade muscle cells and develop into sarcocysts
containing bradyzoites, which are the infective stage for the definitive host
![The number
2](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/stomach_2.gif). Humans
become infected when they eat undercooked meat containing these sarcocysts.
Bradyzoites are released from ruptured cysts in the small intestine ![The
number
3](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/small_intestine_3.gif)
and invade the lamina propria of the intestinal epithelium ![The number
4](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/small_intestine_4.gif).
There, they differentiate into macro- and microgametocytes. Fusion of male and
female gametes ![The number
5](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/small_intestine_5.gif)
results in the formation of oocysts ![The number
6](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/small_intestine_6.gif).
Oocysts sporulate in the intestinal epithelium and are shed from the host in
feces ![The number
7](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/large_intestine_7.gif).
Due to the fragile nature of the oocyst wall, individual sporocysts may also
be detected in feces.

### Geographic Distribution

Worldwide, but more common in areas where livestock is raised.

### Clinical Presentation

In cases of intestinal sarcocystosis, when humans serve as the definitive
hosts, infections are often asymptomatic and clear spontaneously.
Occasionally, mild fever, diarrhea, chills, vomiting and respiratory problems
may occur. When humans become infected with sarcocysts of non-human species,
the infections are not intestinal but rather result in muscle cysts; symptoms
such as myalgia, muscle weakness and transitory edema may occur. In these
cases, humans are dead-end intermediate hosts.
image_gallery:
#####  _Sarcocystis_ oocysts in wet mounts.

Oocysts of _Sarcocystis_ in human feces measure 15-20 µm long by 15-20 µm
wide. Oocysts sporulate in the intestinal epithelium and contain two
sporocysts, each of which contains four sporozoites and a refractile residual
body. Due to the fragile nature of mature oocysts, both sporulated oocysts and
individual sporocysts may be shed in feces. Sporocysts will autofluoresce
under ultraviolet (UV) microscopy.

#####  _Sarcocystis_ sarcocysts in tissue.

Only two species of _Sarcocystis_ are known to utilize humans as a definitive
host: _S. hominis_ and _S. suihominis_. Humans become dead-end hosts when they
ingest the oocysts of _Sarcocystis_ species whose definitive hosts are
mammalian species other than humans. These non-human _Sarcocystis_ spp. will
form structures known as sarcocysts in tissue; these sarcocysts contain
numerous bradyzoites. Sarcocysts are usually found in skeletal or cardiac
muscle.

![](/dpdx/sarcocystosis/images/4/Sarcocystis_muscle_HE_MI_2_rotated.jpg?_=00602)

Figure A: Sarcocysts of _Sarcocystis_ sp. in muscle tissue, stained with
hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). Notice the bradyzoites within each sarcocyst.
Images courtesy of the William Beaumont Hospital, Royal Oak, MI.

![](/dpdx/sarcocystosis/images/4/Sarcocystis_500x1_muscle.jpg?_=00599)

![](/dpdx/sarcocystosis/images/4/Sarcocystis_muscle_HE_MI.jpg?_=00601)

Figure B: Sarcocysts of _Sarcocystis_ sp. in muscle tissue, stained with

Images courtesy of the William Beaumont Hospital, Royal Oak, MI.

lab_diagnosis:
### Laboratory Diagnosis

For intestinal sarcocystosis caused by _S. hominis_ and _S. suihominis_ ,
diagnosis is made by the observation of oocysts or sporocysts in stool. They
are easily overlooked as they are often shed in small numbers. Also, the two
species cannot be separated by oocyst or sporocyst morphology. When humans
serve as dead-end hosts for non-human Sarcocystis spp., diagnosis is made by
the finding of sarcocysts in tissue specimens.

More on: [Morphologic comparison with other intestinal
parasites.](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/diagnosticProcedures/stool/morphcomp.html)
